title: Opioid Pharmacogenomics: More Than Metabolism

author: Andrew Somogyi, School of Medical Sciences, University of Adelaide

segmentation: OK, thank you very much.
Mitchell and I'd like to thank the organizing Committee for inviting me to give this talk.
So just an overview of what I'll be talking about.
I will talk about a little bit of metabolism and a bit of the history about the two D6 and some of these opioids I've mentioned here.
Some work we've been doing with the fentanyl, an 3A, Four 5.
And then focus more on pharmacodynamic.
Genomics as Munir has indicated early on in his excellent to lecture talking about the.
In this case the MU receptor.
Jane and his polymorphisms and the influence of ethnicity.
And then, finally, I'm going to talk about some work we've been doing with the innate immune system, and particularly some of the genes and how polymorphisms in those can influence a pain response.
And finally, because this is a session which deals with also translation, I'll talk about a little bit about translation and perhaps what we might be able to take home with us.
So all this stems from the fact that opioids have a very wide variability between people in how they respond to the drug and dosage requirements.
And of course, these are drugs with a very narrow therapeutic index.
Because if we go too high, we get into respiratory depression.
Too low and the patient is still suffering from pain.
And I've just highlighted here some of the variability we find in dosage requirements.
But the other important aspect is the phenotype.
Pain is very much a subjective experience.
It's as you're well aware, so unpleasant sensory emotional experience which is associated with actual or potential tissue damage or described in such terms.
So I've got this really subjective phenotype embedding on what we want to do in terms of genomics and of course there are multi factors involved like tolerance and hyperalgesia.
So I'm going to be talking a little bit about the Pharmaco genomics with respect to kinetic sand metabolism.
I won't talk about transporters because it's confusing to me as well and I'll be talking about the pharmacodynamics and essentially a lot of this is still the candidate gene approach.
Now, as you're well aware, the CYP 2D6 is a major enzymatic polymorphism discovered by our chair in the mid 1970s, and he keeps reminding me of that.
So you're well aware we've got.
Pull metabolizes various frequencies in Caucasian populations and of course the ultra rapid metabolizers and these two form the basis of how they may impact on opioid kinetics response.

So 25 years ago we looked at coding and in those days we can only phenotype subjects for two D6 and we use the prototypic phenotyping drug dextromethorphan then to essentially show that if you are a poor metabolizer of dextromethorphan, you're also a poor metabolizer of the oxidation of coding to morphine.
And these results we indicated in our paper might indicate that some people 'cause they can't afford morphine be receiving a drug that's potentially inactive.
And that's based on the fact that Morphine's got an affinity for the mu receptor of about 200 times that of codeine.
What's the clinical evidence?
Well, certainly poor metabolizers have much lower concentrations of morphine and in experimental pain they get a very poor response.
But there actually being no clinical pain studies.
To actually prove that.
But it's always written or just read review the other day saying poor metabolizers won't get an analgesic response, so do something else about it.
So there's been no clinical trials.
I guess it's the.
I've called it Captain Obvious we would in Australia call it's a bloody obvious thing.
You don't form any morphine, you don't get a pain response, but I'm just saying there's been no study and there won't be any study.
I suspect.
On the other hand, the Ultra rapid metabolizers have increased morphine concentrations, but can get into trouble in terms of respiratory depression, an they've even been reports of death and.

Quite sadly in in neonates as well, which prompted the FDA to issue a black box warning, and there being subsequent modifications to that, I should say the one person who we thought might have been an Ultra rapid metabolizer who got into respiratory distress problems on 10 milligrams of codeine.
Was not an Ultra rapid metabolizer, that's another story.
The opioid which is consumed the most in prescriptions is oxycodone and it has a similar story compared with codeine.
Eggette oxidized to oxymorphone which has about 100 fold higher potency for them you receptor and again in healthy subjects decrease pain response.
Hardly any responsible, but the clinical studies really show no effect on oxycodone dosage or pain or adverse effects.
And then on the other hand, the Ultra rapid metabolizers who have much higher concentrations of oxymorphone.
Get a good pain response in experimental pain in subjects, but clinical studies really don't show much of an effect at all.
Once more studies showing a decrease response.
So to some extent, although I think I'm changing my mind a little bit, the jury is still out.
One area, one opioid, where it may be important is with tramadol.
It too undergoes an O demethylation here to a what's called the M1 metabolite.
An again in experimental pain.
Those subjects get a very poor cold pressor response here.
And there's been one good clinical study in post operative surgical patients showing a much higher frequency of nonresponders who RPMS compared with responders.
I can pay with Ames and there been reports of respiratory depression.

We've been working with the European Pharmaco genomics of Opioid Study Group of over 2000 cancer patients from different countries and centers throughout Europe, and they've collected data on the different opioids.
An whole bunch of demographic data as well.
And we looked at fentanyl.
And there are about 600 or so cancer patients.
On a transdermal Patch, the.
50 fold or more dosage range variability to get to a particular pain response.
They had plasma concentrations showing at 16,000 fold range and kind of get any bigger, probably not, and the major metabolite North Central showed over 2 1/2 thousand fold range.
And when we looked at what determined.

That plasma concentration of fentanyl obviously dose rate was important, but also gender with males requiring lower concentrations, BMI and inducers and inhibitors, but also the three or four Star 22 and 385 star three were also major contributors to well well contributors to that variability, but overall we could explain about 50% in the variability of the concentration.

But we were more interested in the metabolic ratio of fentanyl to, nor fentanyl, which is primarily determined by the enzyme activity of 345, and certainly the star Wang three or five Star one carriers and three or four Star 22 carriers.

There was a significant Association with that metabolic ratio going in the right direction, but overall you know their contribution to the variability in that 6000 fold metabolic ratio range, while as well almost nothing, it's 2%.
And then when we looked at all the other potential patient and and other factors, we could only explain about 14% in total.
So you know, we were rather disappointed here.
Becausw.
This metabolic ratio should only be determined basically by the enzyme activity.
And we could hardly find any major contributors, so it may be back to the.
The board with that.

But if you know PK metabolism doesn't explain a lot about pharmacodynamics, and Munir pointed that out in his lecture this morning, so I'm going to talk about the mu opioid receptor and I'm going to be talking about the innate immune system.
So as we're all well aware, the target for drugs like morphine, oxycodone is the.
You're an immune receptor.
It has a gene name oprn one.
There are more than 3000 polymorphisms identified in the Thousand Genomes Project, and over thousand I've got a minor meal frequency of more than 1%.
A couple of common nonsynonymous nips Anna huge number of splice variants.
The major one which has been investigated is called A18G.
It's an asparagine to aspartic acid exchange, and it leads to a reduction in M RNA and actually the protein itself.
Loss of function.
The interesting observation is that in Caucasians as the frequency of about 12%, but in the Asian populations it's more than 40%, and we still don't know the reason why.
So you can show in healthy volunteers that this is a study from your English in Frankfurt on experimental pain, showing that those were the G variant had a lower response.
And you can also show a lower effect on respiration of that G of that G variant.
That's all very well.
He then did a meta analysis of the available information on that polymorphism.
And concluded basically that the evidence for the relevance of this polymorphism sort of in clinical practice didn't didn't stand up.
And this has been cited on numerous occasions and at that time I think it was reasonable.
The problem is he had a lump all the different pain phenotypes together.
Experimental pain, cancer pain, postoperative pain, etc.
Many opioids had the lump them all together and each may have a different.
I want IG fingerprint on the actual variability in dosage, low patient numbers an the majority of the.
Patients in this meta analysis were Caucasian.
So basically said forget about it.
But I'm not exactly convinced by that this is a study from Alyxia.
In Singapore, weather over almost 600 Chinese women, two 30,000,000 /, 100 Indian women undergoing cesarean delivery with spinal anesthesia.
PCA, morphine, and they're able to show a small but significant, I guess gene dose affect those that had they 818 GG variant required.
Higher doses overall compared with.
The heterozygotes and homozygous wild type.
And here I've summarized most of the studies that have been conducted in post operative pain in the Asian populations.
It's mainly being PCA, morphine as being the endpoint, the measure.
And you can see it ranges from.
These are all statistically significant, from about 20% increased dosage requirements to over or to about 75% dosage requirements.
Why's that?
Well ethnicity per say may be a factor, but I think it's the G variant which is also a major controlling factor because it's almost 5050% in the population.
And that Springs to mind Mooneys talk on on the US COAG study where they had hardly any variance.
So if you don't have many variants in your population, then as we would say, you're stuffed.
So that's one of the reason.
But morphine also acts on other targets.
In particular, it binds to an accessory protein of toll like receptor 4 called MD 2 and has a sort of affinity of about four micromolar.
Although it's very hard to do that because the prototype drug was not really good anyway, it can alter toll like receptor for signaling.
It can activate and release a number of pro inflammatory cytokines like.
R1 beta in Aisle 6 to actually increase pain sensitivity so it's similar mechanism to that of LPS.

So in this little sort of cartoon, I've tried to indicate here what's going on, so we've got the mu receptor, which is inhibiting activation of the pain signal in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord, but also it's.
Inhibit it's activating the.
The inhibition of the descending inhibition.
So that's sort of the morphine type effect, but also we have this toll like receptor four effect and then mainly on micro glia where this is happening to sort of oppose.
That's so I've got this mu receptor analgesia through morphine and that's being sort of somewhat opposed by toll like receptor 4 Activation pro inflammatory cytokines.
And there have been studies, sort of in the past showing an effect in cancer patients of an aisle 6 promoter and in post operative pain with an aisle one receptor antagonist.
No need to go to enter that in any detail, so there's some footprints in the sand there regarding some of these proinflammatory cytokine genes influencing opioid requirement.
So we've set up this, I guess a night immune cellular pathway chip as it were.

Where we've been looking at the major polymorphisms insider kind signaling, particularly I'll 1 beta, and then I'll 10 and I'll 6 and a few others, and in the not what we call non classical opioid signaling through toll like receptors for and to.
Of course MD 2 and then we also obviously looking at the classical opioid receptor OPRN 1G, and these are all sort of shown in this bit of a cartoon here.
But the end result is, you know we're getting this pro inflammatory response, which can cause pain itself.
So we're interested in seeing whether it could explain some of the variability in pain response and opioid requirements.
So I showed you this before.
This is from Alex here in Singapore with his postoperative pain, cesarean delivery cohort of patients.
And as you see, the frequency of the G variant as he showed before we repeated this and got 100% concordance, which is amazing.
But the point I want to make here is in this cohort, the pain phenotype that was mild to moderate pain.

The opioid requirements was was quite small but lots of variability as one might expect, but their pain scores at zero time when they're coming out of surgery was also quite small, something like 5% of them had a vascular, about 0, so zero is no pain.
10 is excruciating pain.
And overall their pain scores were quite low.
But anyway, when we.
I did some of the the analysis here.
We did in fact find that I'll 1 beta and TLR.
Two and BDNF were significantly associated with morphine consumption, whereas I'll 6 and TLR four, and I'll ten were associated with reduced morphine consumption.
So we've got this sort of counterbalance.
There were also interested in, well, that's all very good, but cannot predict what percentage prediction of how much morphine is to be used.
So when we put this into our model.

Basically, in the Chinese and Malay women we came up with about a 5%, no more maximum predicted variability, but in the Indian population and only 130, three of them, we could actually explain 22% of their morphine requirements.
So you know, we think that the innate immune markers may play a role in morphine requirements in this multi moderate pain, and we're now looking another cohort.
Of women undergoing against Syrian delivery but under general anaesthesia, where their morphine requirements were much higher?
The other thing I want to point out is that when we did this genotyping, we found significant and huge differences between Caucasians and these other cohorts, but also within them.
For example, the aisle 1 beta promoter snippet was.
The frequency of it in chanting the Chinese women was sevenfold lower than in Caucasians.
Was only about 20 or 30% lower in the Indian population.
On the other hand, toll like receptor four.
That snip was substantially lower frequency in Chinese but will substantially higher.
It was like 3 or 4% higher in the Indian population.
So it really depends on your cohort of patients where some of these genes may become important.
And that's the message that I want to get across.
We've also just started now looking at our fentanyl Patch.
Patients from the post study and group of them.
I think about it was about a third or or more had were in a cohort.

Good pain relief, no side effects as opposed to variations of the others, and we're interested in seeing what determines that fentanyl concentration to get them into that cohort and toll like receptor for the heterozygotes.
We didn't have any homozygous showed a higher requirement or higher concentrations needed to get them into that good pain.
No adverse effects cohort statistically significant.
But contributing very little to the overall model.
Where to from here?

Well, there was a genius study in Japanese surgical patients showing that a histone methyltransferase showed those that had the homozygous variant are required much higher amounts of opioid compared with other two groups.
And there's one study from your lunch showing that there's some epigenetic factors coming in here where he showed a higher methylation rate and one position particular position in the oprn 1 gene.
But you know the magnitude difference was not that great, and it wasn't.
Weekly well it was weekly rated pain scores.
Can any of this be translated well, you know, does it have to be?
Can't we just gain some knowledge here?
I know of two US companies here who are advertising.
To doctors to get the patients DNA and do they do genotyping to improve pain response, reduce adverse effects?
And here's an Australian company basically doing the same thing.
It's all PK, and it's all two D6 and it's all codeine who would wanna genotyped coding in every patient anyway and oxycodone and tramadol.
The other point I want to get across here is again, as I mentioned earlier, it's the phenotype and all the studies that have been conducted have difficulties in what's the pain?
What's the source of the pain?
Is it surgical pain?
Is it you know cancer, pain, etc.
Population stratification.
I think ethnicity is quite important.
Sample sizes of being small.
We have the whole issue of a person's culture and a person's background on influencing their, their opioid and pain response anxiety catastrophizing becoming poor.
So this is my take home message.
We would like to have the the straight Rd showing that this is all very important clinically and we should get this out and without having to do a randomized control trial.
But we actually end up with a long and winding Rd as The Beatles would say.
Hopefully we might get somewhere in the future.
I hope this was going to be a Golden goose, but it ain't.
It's a I think it's a Swan or still trying to chase it.
But in terms of metabolism, 2D6 is important mainly for adverse effects that can arise in a very small percentage of the population.
Some evidence for tramadol clinically in post operative pain.
But we in Australia don't use it in their context in terms of pharmacodynamics.
The Oprn 1 gene polymorphism the A118G I think is important, but in the Asian population.
We're seeing some effects now with innate immune genes of these ones here at others, but again, it may be an ethnicity factor that's contributing cause of increased frequency.

But also we need to remember it's the patient psychology, culture, pain, types that are very important factors that impinge on all this, so I think this is more than metabolism, but I don't think we're ready at all for general translation.
If that ever might arise.
So I just like to thank these groups who have collaborated with over several years and it also like to acknowledge Mishali Shabam, who I did.
My postdoc with him back in the good old days in bond he taught me a lot and continues to teach me a lot.
So thank you very much.
The issue about local inflammation makes sense, you know, and we known about inflammation contributing to pain for a long time.
So in your studies, particularly the cancer patients, some will be on non steroidal.
So does that affect your results?
And you correct for that confounding?
You're right, not all of them are on nonsteroidal Zan, it's being corrected for OK and when you correct it do you get a better R-squared value or not?
Unfortunately, but you know, that's the way it goes.
You showed some very nice jeans to look at one of them which was missing with the chemical or material transfer rates which has been out in the literature consistently.
Did you look at that and why did you not include it in your results?
The answer is yes.
But with the caveat here.
Alex, he said all we've only got a third of the patients, so we put them in the model and it didn't have any effect.
Then when I met up with him two weeks ago in Singapore, his laboratory assistant said no, Alex, we've got them all.
So they've just sending us all the DNA and we're going to do.
We're going well, sorry they've done the comp and we're just going to put it into our model, but even they even at that smoke small cohort, it had no effect.
But it did have an effect.
On nausea and vomiting, even in 1/3 of the patients where we had the DNA.
So we think that might be interesting, so I'll let you know once we have the whole yeah.

How do you?

And.

Put them on oxycodone and are OK, but only about 20% and vice versa.
So you're right, there are.
Some intracellular signaling elements that need to be looked at as well.
Rachel I was interested in whether you think any of these signaling pathways isn't innate pathways.
That it makes sense that they affect pain.
Do you think they are also going to affect abuse liability or are they just in such a different sort of realm of the spectrum?
I'm not.
That in our pilot data they don't seem to have a major effect on abuse liability, although I'm saying that very carefully 'cause we don't have big numbers.
But we have looked at alcoholism and there's a significant Association of toll like 4 snip with alcoholism so.
Name your poison.
Thank you.
